feed.title: It's a Dog's Life
feed.subtitle: Wilfred creator/star Jason Gann on sending erection photos, making Elijah Wood win his role and the secret to his cult success

link.Abstract: Wilfred creator/star Jason Gann on sending erection photos, making Elijah Wood win his role and the secret to his cult success
link.title: [ more ]

content.div:
Mere moments before he's to discuss his new cult comedy, Wilfred, with Dose.ca, Australian actor Jason Gann looks at his phone and laughs. It's one of those laughs loud enough to invite questions and without hesitation the creator of one of the most surreal shows to ever make it on to American television launches into a story:

"When I left for this promo trip I asked a friend of mine to look after my cats; not a good friend mind you, just a decent friend," he begins. Aside from the ironic revelation that a man that spends a good percentage of his life in a dog costume is, in fact, a cat owner, nothing out of the ordinary there. "Anyways," he continues, "she send me an e-mail this morning informing me that she's fed the cat and they seem happy…" and here comes the kicker, "So I sent her back a photo of myself in my underwear with a huge erection."

All of which is to say, Gann is clearly a fan of uncomfortable human interaction.

It's that brand of uneasy humour that defines both Gann and his off-beat creation which began life as a seven minute short nearly a decade ago. Wilfred's premise hasn't changed much since those early days: A suicidal man named Ryan (Elijah Wood) has a crush on his neighbour, Jenna (Fiona Gubelmann), whose dog Wilfred (Gann) appears to him as a crude human in a dog suit. It's a simple foundation, but in the capable hands of someone as off-kilter as Gann, simplicity is the devil's playground.

"As a writer I'd heard that Hollywood runs on good ideas and that's the one thing I knew that I had," Gann recalls of his decision to sell the format rights to the show – which had become a successful Australian series – to American networks.

Sliding back in his chair at Toronto's the Rivoli, he allows a sly smile to cross his face as he explains the response to his pitch.

"They said, ‘Look, we can sell this, but you've got to be in it,'" he laughs. "So I unintentionally came and sold myself and now I'm starring in my own show, which is a dream I had 20 years ago which had all but been knocked out of me."

Ego boost aside, Gann was aware the road to cross-continental television success, especially with such an unconventional show, was littered with the corpses of failure.

"I was really aware of reintroducing this character [in America] because Wilfred could become an unlikeable character very quickly if you don't introduce him into the story well," he says. "It's about getting that chemistry right; it's about getting that first meeting between Ryan and Wilfred so right."

Consequently, Wilfred's success (FX has already ordered a second season) is just as much due to Gann as it is his pint-sized costar. The two work off each other in subtle ways, conversing through body language and using their contrasting personalities push one another against the grain of being a normal, well adjusted, character.

Surprisingly, Wood was not the immediate choice for the lead role, having to audition several times before landing the part.

"He wasn't the only high profile person that was interested and he didn't instantly get the role either, he really won it," Gann says. "We met each other and the connection was instant."

Perhaps Wilfred's biggest obstacle to crossover success was its lead characters anti-hero status – an issue that the barbed writer conquered by establishing the parameters of his creation.

"When you counter balance him chasing one of those laser dots you realize he's just a dog," Gann explains, noting that humans have a natural inclination to forgive animals. "Dogs get away with things in relationships that people never would. You'd never pick up your best friend's shit unless…he was a dog. So in that sense I think people are forgiving of Wilfred's more annoying traits."

Wilfred debuts on Oct. 31 at 11 p.m. ET/PT on FX Canada
